  • Electronic Supplier Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority

entry.title: Empowering Teams to Streamline Sales and Service Operations with SAP Build Joule Skills
entry.content:
🌟Introduction to SAP Build Joule Skills

In today’s fast-changing business landscape, automation, intelligence, and integration are essential for success. SAP Build Joule Skills bring these elements together to help businesses optimize workflows, streamline project management, and automate repetitive processes like project opportunity creation, quote management, and customer service handling.

By combining SAP Joule’s intelligent automation with SAP’s enterprise-grade solutions, organizations can increase productivity, ensure accuracy, and empower employees to focus on high-value work.

🚨Please refer to the video for better understanding.🚨

🤖What Are SAP Build Joule Skills?

SAP Build Joule Skills are customizable automation capabilities built within the SAP ecosystem. They allow users to create intelligent workflows that respond to business needs — whether it’s creating new sales opportunities, generating quotes, or handling service requests.

✨Key Features of Joule Skills:

  • Automation: Reduce manual data entry by automating repetitive tasks.
  • Integration: Connect seamlessly with SAP and non-SAP systems.
  • Scalability: Create and manage skills that grow with your organization.
  • User-Friendly: Empower business users with low-code/no-code design tools.

🧠 What Is SAP Build Joule?

SAP Build Joule is part of the SAP Build portfolio — a low-code platform that enables business and IT users to collaboratively design, automate, and innovate processes. Joule brings an AI-powered digital assistant into this ecosystem, helping users perform complex tasks through simple, conversational interactions.

🪄 Key Benefits:

  • Accelerated automation – Build and deploy workflows faster.
  • No-code customization – Design automation logic without needing deep technical skills.
  • AI-driven insights – Use AI to make decisions faster and improve efficiency.

🌟Story:

It was another busy morning at Conva Engineering. Adrian Chase, an account manager, had a full agenda — new project sites to manage and quotes to prepare for contractors working across the site, and a customer issue waiting for resolution.

In the past, this would have meant hours of manual coordination: filling out spreadsheets, sending multiple emails, and ensuring every quote aligned with customer requirements. But since his company adopted SAP Joule, Adrian’s workday looks very different.

He starts his day by opening SAP Joule, the AI-powered assistant integrated within the company’s SAP landscapes.

“Joule, please create a new project.”

Joule instantly responds:

“Sure, please provide the site name, customer, and materials to be quoted.”

Adrian enters the details: the site name “Free Text”, the customer details, and three product codes — 5079, 5080, and 5081.

Within moments, Joule creates the new project opportunity, generates the required quotes for the contractors bidding on the site contract, and organizes all related data within the project opportunity.

Later that morning, when a damaged product report comes in from a client, Adrian simply instructs Joule to raise a credit request.

“A service case has been created and linked to the project,” Joule confirms.

Without opening multiple applications or chasing emails, the issue is automatically routed to customer service with sales order data for processing the credit extracted via AI, ensuring a fast response and complete traceability.

By leveraging SAP Joule, Adrian has transformed what used to be a time-consuming, manual process into an intelligent, automated workflow.

Now, he spends less time managing tasks — and more time building relationships, exploring new opportunities, and driving strategic growth.

🧩 SAP Products That Power Joule Skills

SAP Joule Skills are designed to work seamlessly across multiple SAP solutions, forming a connected ecosystem for business excellence. Here are some key SAP products that enhance and integrate with Joule:

⚙️SAP Build

  • The foundation for creating Joule Skills.
  • Allows both business users and developers to design, automate, and test workflows through a low-code environment.

🧾 SAP S/4HANA Cloud

  • Central to managing projects, quotes, and sales orders.
  • Joule connects directly with S/4HANA data to fetch customer, product, and pricing details in real time.

💬SAP Sales Cloud

  • Integrates with Joule to streamline the quote-to-order process.
  • Ensures sales teams can generate accurate quotes and track opportunities efficiently.

🤝SAP Customer Experience (CX)

  • Improves collaboration between sales and customer support.
  • Joule automates ticket creation, credit requests, and case tracking for customer satisfaction.

🧰 SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

  • The underlying infrastructure that connects all SAP solutions.
  • Ensures secure, scalable, and high-performance integration between Joule Skills and enterprise systems.

💼Use Case: Project Opportunity & Quote Creation

Let’s look at a real-world example featuring Adrian Chase, a sales professional who uses SAP Joule to manage project opportunities, quotes, and service requests seamlessly.

Step 1: Create a New Project

Arian launches the Joule app from his workspace and starts a new project. Joule asks for key information such as the site name, customer details, and materials to be quoted.

Step 2:Create Opportunity

 

Opportunity created in Sales Cloud V2.

The Same Opportunity  is replicated to S4HANA public cloud as an Project 

 

S4HANA Customer Project replication from V2 Sales Opportunity 

 

Step 3: Create a Quote and Associate It with the Existing Opportunity

 

Every quote created is associated with an existing opportunity

Step 4: Handle Service Requests

Arian needs to issue a credit for a damaged product.

 

Case created is associated with an existing opportunity

 

Final 

 

Video

 

 

🚀Why Joule Skills Matter for Businesses

1. Time Efficiency

  • Automate manual processes like project setup, quote generation, and service requests to save time.

2. Accuracy & Data Consistency

  • Reduce errors through system-driven data capture and validation.

3. Improved Collaboration

  • Connect sales, service, and operations teams through unified data flows.

4. Scalable Innovation

  • Quickly adapt Joule Skills to handle new business needs without complex development.

5. AI-Powered Productivity

  • Leverage SAP Joule’s conversational AI to guide employees through complex workflows.

 

🌈Conclusion

SAP Build Joule Skills empower organizations to automate end-to-end workflows, from project creation to customer service handling. When combined with SAP Build, SAP S/4HANA, Sales Cloud, and CX, Joule becomes a central intelligence hub that drives efficiency, consistency, and growth.

By integrating your business processes into Joule Skills, you can:

  • Reduce operational overhead,
  • Enhance customer satisfaction, and
  • Enable teams to focus on strategic goals.

💡Start building your Joule Skills today — and transform the way your business works with the power of SAP!

entry.title: Joule Capability Documentation Chat
entry.content:
As use cases involving AI become increasingly intertwined with our lives, we have developed a documentation chat for ABAP developers. The documentation chat is available for you to ask questions and find solutions to any ABAP development problem you may have. The conversation with the documentation chat should help you solve your tasks and serve as your helpful guide.

In this blog, we explain the rationale behind the documentation chat, how to use it, and what it offers in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511.

 

Rationale

Our primary goal is to provide easy access to the ABAP Cloud product documentation and to enhance the accessibility and findability of our content. Finding documentation has always been an issue that’s often caused by missing semantics in the provided content. To address this issue, we employ retrieval-augmented generation to deliver relevant information in response to a query.

 

Using the Documentation Chat

The documentation chat is available as a Joule capability in ABAP development tools for Eclipse. For information about using Joule in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, refer to Opening the Joule Chat View.

To use the documentation chat, follow these steps:

  1. In the Joule view, select the button /.
  2. Choose docs.

    If you send the request without a prompt, you receive a description of the capability.
  3. Enter your question in the text area.

     



  4. Press Enter or select the Select message (Enter) button.

    You receive a response to your question. The answer can include text, bullet points, and code examples. Also, references are always provided, allowing you to view the source documentation and verify the given answer.

 

Supported Documentation

As of SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511, the documentation chat includes the following documentation:

  • ABAP Keyword Documentation
  • ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model
  • ABAP Data Models
  • ABAP Cloud

When chatting with the documentation, you can expect assistance with the topics in the documentation above. It is also possible to ask follow-up questions after an initial question, as the chat history is respected.

In the coming releases, you can expect more to come. Feel free to leave a comment or a like.

entry.title: Archiving Enterprise Projects (EPPM) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management (EPPM) projects can accumulate over time. Closed or obsolete projects that remain in the system increase data volume and negatively affect reporting clarity and system performance.

In addition, there are practical scenarios where projects are created incorrectly and already moved to status Released — for example, due to wrong organizational assignments, incorrect project profiles, or test creations in productive systems. Since such projects cannot simply be deleted once released, archiving becomes the only compliant way to remove them from operational usage.

In this blog post, I will show how to archive Enterprise Projects using the ILM-enabled archiving object /S4PPM/PRO , including prerequisites, ILM configuration, archiving execution, monitoring, and optional data destruction.

1. Prerequisites 

1.1. Required scope item

Archiving of Enterprise Projects is available only if the following scope item is activated:

  • 1KA – Information Lifecycle Management 

  • 1NT – Project Control - Finance 

1.2. Required user roles

Ensure that your user has the following roles assigned:

Business RoleBusiness Role ID
Project Financial ControllerSAP_BR_PROJ_FIN_CONTROLLER
Configuration Expert – Business Process ConfigurationSAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT

If you don’t have the required roles, contact your administrator or refer to the Maintain Business Users app.

1.3. Functional prerequisites for EPPM projects

An Enterprise Project can only be archived if all of the following conditions are met:

  • The project status is Closed

  • A residence period is defined and has ended
    (controlled via ILM policies, described below)

  • No assigned orders exist (sales orders, purchase orders, etc.)

  • No actual cost postings exist

  • No attachments (assigned documents) exist

If any assigned orders, actual postings, or attachments exist for the project or its WBS elements, these objects must be archived first.

1.4 ILM configuration prerequisites

To enable archiving of Enterprise Projects, several ILM-related configuration steps must be completed.

1.4.1 Maintain Audit Area

An audit area is a logical grouping of one or more ILM objects based on a specific business purpose. These objects can be retrieved for various audit-related scenarios, such as tax or financial audits, as well as warranty and product liability claims.

Audit areas are a mandatory prerequisite for defining ILM policies. An ILM object must be assigned to an audit area before residence or retention rules can be created.

To define an Audit Area, log on to SAP Central Business Configuration.
Open the Configuration app and search for the configuration activity Maintain Audit Area. Open the activity to access the audit area maintenance screen.

 

In the Maintain Audit Area configuration, choose Edit and then select New Entries. Enter the Audit Area technical name, provide a meaningful Description, and select the appropriate Policy Category.

The Policy Category defines how data lifecycle rules are applied:

  • Retention Rules specify the minimum and maximum time data must be retained, including the relevant time reference and optional offsets. These rules are typically driven by legal or regulatory requirements.

  • Residence Rules specify how long data must remain in the database before it becomes eligible for archiving, based on a defined residence duration and time reference.

Selecting the correct policy category is critical because it determines which ILM rules can be maintained later. In practice, residence rules control when Enterprise Projects can be archived, while retention rules control how long archived data must be kept before deletion.

After entering all required fields, save your changes. The audit area is now available for assigning ILM objects and for maintaining ILM policies and rules in subsequent configuration st

1.4.2 Assign ILM Object to Audit Area

At this step, you need to assign an ILM object to an audit area. This is a mandatory prerequisite for maintaining ILM policies and rules and for enabling archiving of the corresponding business object.

To assign an ILM object to an Audit Area, log on to SAP Central Business Configuration.
Open the Configuration app and search for the configuration activity Assign ILM Object to Audit Area. Open the activity to proceed with the assignment.

In the Assign ILM Object to Audit Area configuration, select the relevant Policy Category and Audit Area, and then choose Run.

On the next screen, switch to Edit mode and select New Entries. Enter the ILM object /S4PPM/PRO and set the Status to Active, then save your entry.

The archiving object /S4PPM/PRO is responsible for archiving Enterprise Projects and includes the following data:

  • Project header data (including milestones, entitlements, and status values)

  • WBS elements

  • Planned costs (at both project and WBS level)

  • Change documents

Repeat this step for both previously defined Audit Areas — one with the Policy Category Retention Rules and one with the Policy Category Residence Rules — to ensure that both retention and residence policies can be evaluated for the Enterprise Project archiving object.

If you need to adjust an existing assignment, select the corresponding entry, choose Edit, update the Status as required (for example, set it to Inactive), and save the changes.

1.4.3 Maintain ILM Policies and Rules

At this step, you define ILM policies and rules that control how long Enterprise Project data must remain in the system and when it becomes eligible for archiving or destruction. Policies and rules are maintained per ILM object and Audit Area and are a mandatory prerequisite for ILM-based archiving.

To maintain ILM policies and rules, log on to SAP Central Business Configuration.
Open the Configuration app and search for the configuration activity Maintain ILM Policies and Rules. Open the activity to proceed with the policy maintenance.

In the configuration screen, select the relevant ILM Object, Policy Category (Residence Rules), and Audit Area, and then choose Run.

On the next screen, switch to Edit mode and select New Entries to create a new ILM policy. Enter a Policy Name and Status.

When creating the policy, ensure that the Status is set to Not Live. Only policies with status Not Live can be customized, allowing you to define condition fields and maintain residence or retention rules.

After all rules have been defined and reviewed, the policy status can be changed to Live to activate it.

After creating the ILM policy, you can define Condition Fields. Condition fields allow you to control which Enterprise Projects the ILM rules apply to, based on specific project attributes.

To maintain condition fields, select Condition Fields in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In the Condition Fields section, choose New Entries and define the condition fields that should be evaluated when the ILM rules are applied. Each condition field is maintained with a Position, which determines the evaluation order of the conditions.

For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, SAP provides several available condition fields, such as:

  • Project Profile

  • Company Code

  • Profit Center

  • Responsible Cost Center

  • Plant

In our example, Project Profile (PROFILEID) is used as a condition field. This allows you to define different residence or retention rules depending on the project profile, for example distinguishing between overhead, investment, or statistical projects.

After defining the condition fields, you need to maintain Residence Rules for the ILM policy. Residence rules determine how long an Enterprise Project must remain in the database before it becomes eligible for archiving.

To define residence rules, select Residence Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side and switch to Edit mode. Choose New Entries to create a new rule.

For each residence rule, maintain the following fields:

  • Residence Period – defines the length of time the project must remain in the database before archiving is allowed. The residence period is evaluated together with the time reference and time unit.

  • Time Unit – specifies the unit of the residence period, such as days, months, or years.

  • Time Reference – determines the event in the project lifecycle that serves as the starting point for the residence period. For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, a common time reference is Date of Last Change (CHANGE_DATE).

  • Time Offset – allows you to shift the start date of the residence period to the end of a calendar unit, such as the end of a month, quarter, or year.

  • Rule Number – a system-assigned identifier used to uniquely identify the rule.

  • Priority – defines the precedence of the rule when multiple rules apply. Higher values indicate higher priority. If no priority is maintained, the default value is 0.

Once saved, the residence rule ensures that Enterprise Projects cannot be archived until the defined residence period has fully expired. This mechanism helps meet legal and operational requirements by preventing premature archiving of project data.

After defining the residence rule itself, you can further refine its scope by maintaining Condition Field Values. This step allows you to specify for which Enterprise Projects the rule applies, based on the condition fields defined earlier.

To maintain condition field values, select Condition Field Values under Residence Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In this example, the condition field Project Profile (PROFILEID) is restricted to the values YP02 (Investment Project) and YP03 (Overhead Project).

After maintaining the required values, activate and save your entries. The residence rule will now be applied only to Enterprise Projects that match both the rule definition and the specified condition field values.

After maintaining and activating the residence rules, you can define Retention Rules. Retention rules determine how long archived Enterprise Project data must be retained and when it becomes eligible for destruction, in accordance with legal and compliance requirements.

In the configuration screen, select the relevant ILM Object (/S4PPM/PRO), change the Policy Category to Retention Rules, select the appropriate Audit Area, and then choose Run.

On the next screen, switch to Edit mode and select New Entries to create a new ILM policy. Enter a Policy Name and Status.

When creating the policy, ensure that the Status is set to Not Live. Only policies with status Not Live can be customized, allowing you to define condition fields and maintain residence or retention rules.

After all rules have been defined and reviewed, the policy status can be changed to Live to activate it.

After creating the ILM policy, you can define Condition Fields. Condition fields allow you to control which Enterprise Projects the ILM rules apply to, based on specific project attributes.

To maintain condition fields, select Condition Fields in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In the Condition Fields section, choose New Entries and define the condition fields that should be evaluated when the ILM rules are applied. Each condition field is maintained with a Position, which determines the evaluation order of the conditions.

For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, SAP provides several available condition fields, such as:

  • Project Profile

  • Company Code

  • Profit Center

  • Responsible Cost Center

  • Plant

In our example, Project Profile (PROFILEID) is used as a condition field. This allows you to define different residence or retention rules depending on the project profile, for example distinguishing between overhead, investment, or statistical projects.

After defining the condition fields, you need to maintain Retention Rules for the ILM policy. Retention rules determine how long archived Enterprise Project data must be retained and when it becomes eligible for mandatory destruction.

To define retention rules, select Retention Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side and switch to Edit mode. Choose New Entries to create a new rule.

For each retention rule, maintain the following fields:

  • Authorization Group – defines which users are allowed to display archived project data during the retention period. The authorization group must be maintained in the Maintain Authorization Groups for ILM Blocking configuration activity and is used together with the restriction type BLOCKED_DATA.

  • Minimum Retention Period – defines the minimum duration for which archived Enterprise Project data must be retained. The data cannot be deleted before this period has expired. The minimum retention period is evaluated together with the time reference and time unit.

  • Maximum Retention Period – defines the maximum duration for which archived data may be retained. Once this period expires, the data becomes eligible for mandatory destruction.

  • Time Unit – specifies the unit for both minimum and maximum retention periods, such as days, months, or years.

  • Time Reference – determines the event in the project lifecycle that serves as the starting point for the retention period. For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, a common time reference is Date of Last Change (CHANGE_DATE).

  • Time Offset – allows you to shift the start date of the retention period to the end of a calendar unit, such as the end of a month, quarter, or year. This adjusted date is used as the basis for calculating the retention period.

  • Priority – defines the precedence of the rule when multiple retention rules apply. Higher values indicate higher priority. If no priority is maintained, the default value is 0.

Once saved, the retention rule ensures that archived Enterprise Project data is retained for the legally or operationally required period and is only deleted after the defined maximum retention period has expired. This mechanism helps ensure compliance with legal, audit, and data protection requirements.

After defining the retention rule itself, you can further refine its scope by maintaining Condition Field Values. This step allows you to specify for which Enterprise Projects the retention rule applies, based on the condition fields defined earlier in the policy.

To maintain condition field values, select Condition Field Values under Retention Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In this example, the condition field Project Profile (PROFILEID) is restricted to the values YP02 (Investment Project) and YP03 (Overhead Project). This means that the retention rule will only be evaluated for Enterprise Projects that use one of these two project profiles.

After maintaining the required values, save and activate your entries. The retention rule will now be applied only to Enterprise Projects that match both the retention rule definition and the specified condition field values.

2. Archiving Execution

Once all prerequisites are fulfilled — including Enterprise Project status checks and the required ILM configuration — you can proceed with the archiving execution. This phase covers the technical steps required to select eligible projects, run the archiving jobs, and optionally perform data destruction after retention periods expire.

2.1. Manage Archiving Variants and Schedule Archiving Jobs

Use the Manage Archiving Variants app (F0627A) to define which Enterprise Projects should be included in the archiving run.

In the Archiving Objects list on the left-hand side, select Enterprise Projects with the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO. This object represents Enterprise Projects and is used to control their archiving process.

The main screen displays an overview of the selected archiving object, including the last archive run date and the current status of archiving runs. At this point, no runs or variants exist yet, which is why no data is shown.

To proceed, choose Add New Variant in the bottom-right corner of the screen.

Variant Details

  • Name – technical name of the variant. It uniquely identifies the archiving configuration and is mandatory.
  • Description – optional text used to document the purpose of the archiving variant.
  • Variant Type – defines the type of the variant. For Enterprise Projects, the following options are available: 
    • Write – executes the actual archiving run and creates archive files. This variant type is required to archive Enterprise Project data.
    • Preprocessing – performs a preliminary check to determine which projects are eligible for archiving, without archiving any data. It is typically used for validation before executing the write phase.
  • Application Detail Log – controls the level of detail written to the application log. The Complete option is recommended for full transparency and troubleshooting.
  • Test Mode – when enabled, the archiving run is executed in simulation mode. No data is archived, but all checks are performed.
  • Action – defines the operation executed by the variant.
    • Archiving – archives Enterprise Project data.
    • Data Destruction – permanently deletes archived data.

Selection Parameters

  • Project Definition – restricts the archiving run to specific Enterprise Projects.
  • Company Code – limits archiving to projects belonging to a specific company code.
  • Plant – optional restriction based on plant.
  • Profit Center – optional restriction based on profit center.
  • Archiving Session Note – optional field used to document the archiving session.

After maintaining all required fields, choose Save. The archiving variant is now available to schedule and monitor archiving jobs for Enterprise Projects.

 

After saving the variant, return to the previous screen and open the All Variants tab.

On this screen, all archiving variants created for the selected archiving object /S4PPM/PRO (Enterprise Projects) are displayed. You can review each variant’s name, description, and type (for example, Write).

To continue with archiving execution, select the required variant from the list and click the arrow (>) on the right-hand side. This opens the variant details, where you can schedule the archiving run and later monitor its execution status.

On the variant details screen, review the selection parameters and execution settings one final time.

To start the archiving run, click Schedule Archiving at the bottom of the screen. This action schedules an archiving job for the selected variant ARCHIVING_1, based on the defined criteria (for example, Project Definition, Company Code, Plant, or Profit Center).

In the Schedule Archiving dialog, review the technical details of the archiving run.

The system displays the Archiving Object /S4PPM/PRO and the selected Write Variant ARCHIVING_1. These fields are derived from the variant configuration and cannot be changed at this stage.

To confirm and start the archiving run, click Schedule. This action creates a background archiving job for Enterprise Projects based on the defined selection parameters and ILM rules.

Scheduled archiving runs in the production mode are triggered by a technical job which is executed every two days at 20:00 UTC whereas scheduled archiving runs in the test mode are triggered by a technical job which is executed every two hours.

2.2. Monitor Archiving Jobs

After scheduling the archiving run, you can monitor its execution using the Monitor Archiving Jobs (F0510A) app.

This app provides a centralized overview of all archiving jobs for the selected archiving object and allows you to track their execution status and analyze potential issues.

In this screen, you can see an overview of all archiving jobs for the Enterprise Projects archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, grouped by their current status:

  • Scheduled – jobs that are planned but not yet started

  • In Process – jobs currently running

  • Completed – successfully finished jobs

  • Failed – jobs that ended with errors

In the example shown, a Write Job based on the variant ARCHIVING_1 is currently in the Scheduled status. The job has been triggered by the user and is waiting for execution by the system background scheduler.

Once the archiving job has finished processing, it moves to the Completed status.

In this screen, you can see all successfully executed jobs, grouped under Completed jobs. Each entry represents a technical step of the archiving process, such as:

  • Write Job – selects the Enterprise Projects based on the archiving variant and writes the eligible data to the archive files

  • Storage Job – stores the generated archive files in the configured ILM storage

  • Delete Job – removes archived data from the database, if deletion is part of the execution scope

By selecting the arrow (>) icon at the end of a job row, you can drill down into the job details to review application logs and technical messages. This step is essential to confirm that the archiving process for Enterprise Projects has completed successfully and without errors.

After opening a completed Write Job, you can analyze the execution results using the following tabs:

Job Details
This tab provides a structured overview of the archiving run configuration and execution context. It includes the Variant and Variant Description used for the run, execution-related information (such as start time and duration), and the Archiving Session number that uniquely identifies the created archiving session.

Job Log
The Job Log contains the technical execution log of the background job. It shows a chronological sequence of processing steps, including job start, execution of the write program /S4PPM/PROJECT_WRITE creation of the archiving session, generation of archive files, and job completion.

Application Log
The Application Log shows business-level messages generated during the archiving run. It lists which Enterprise Projects were processed, how many objects were archived, and whether the processing was successful or not. This tab is the most relevant for functional verification, as it confirms that the intended projects (for example, specific project definitions or WBS structures) were actually archived.

Together, these three tabs allow you to fully validate both the technical execution and the business outcome of the Enterprise Project archiving run.

2.3. ILM Data Destruction

After Enterprise Projects have been successfully archived and all retention periods have expired, the archived data can be permanently deleted using ILM Data Destruction.

ILM Data Destruction is the final step in the Information Lifecycle Management process. It physically removes archived data from the ILM store and therefore cannot be reversed. For this reason, this step must be performed strictly in accordance with legal, compliance, and internal governance requirements.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ILM Data Destruction is executed using the ILM Data Destruction (F2662) app.

After opening the app, navigate to the Archive Files tab.

On this tab, the system displays all ILM-enabled archiving objects that have archived data eligible for data destruction. Each entry represents an archiving object for which archive files exist in the ILM store.

Locate the Enterprise Projects archiving object /S4PPM/PRO in the list. The Expired Resources column shows the number of archive files whose maximum retention period has expired and which are therefore eligible for permanent deletion.

Select the entry for /S4PPM/PRO and use the navigation arrow (>) to drill down into the list of expired archive files. This step allows you to review which archive files are available for data destruction before proceeding with the deletion process.

After opening the Enterprise Projects archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, the app displays the Resources tab with all archive files that are eligible for data destruction.

In this screen, you can see the list of Expired Resources, including the archive file ID, the Expiration Date, and the Mandatory Destruction Date. The expiration date indicates when the maximum retention period has ended, while the mandatory destruction date defines the latest point in time by which the data must be permanently deleted to comply with legal requirements.

Select the relevant archive file by marking the checkbox and choose Schedule. This action schedules the data destruction job for the selected archive file. Once scheduled and executed, the archive file will be permanently removed from the ILM store and cannot be restored.

After selecting the expired archive file and choosing Schedule, the Schedule Delete dialog is displayed.

In this dialog, the system warns that the selected data will be deleted permanently. Optionally, you can enable Test Mode to simulate the deletion without physically removing the data, which is useful for validation and compliance checks.
To proceed with irreversible data destruction, choose Delete. This schedules the data destruction job and permanently removes the archive file from the ILM store once executed.

After the deletion job has been executed successfully, the archive file is removed from the ILM store and no longer appears in the list of expired resources.

At this point, the Resources view is empty for the selected ILM object, which confirms that the data destruction has been completed successfully.
This indicates the final stage of the Information Lifecycle Management process: the archived Enterprise Project data has been permanently deleted and cannot be recovered.

Summary

In this blog post, we explored how to archive and permanently delete Enterprise Projects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud using the Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) framework.

We walked through the complete end-to-end process: preparing the prerequisites, configuring ILM audit areas and policies, assigning the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, and executing archiving runs using archiving variants. We then reviewed how to monitor archiving jobs and analyze their logs to ensure successful execution.

Finally, we covered the ILM Data Destruction step, where archived project data is permanently deleted once retention periods have expired, completing the lifecycle in a compliant and controlled manner.

This approach helps keep the system clean, ensures compliance with legal retention requirements, and provides a structured and auditable way to manage the full lifecycle of Enterprise Project data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

entry.title: Sales Order Pricing Trigger Based on Custom Field
entry.content:
This blog shows how the Sales Order pricing can be triggered when a custom field is populated or updated in a Sales Order.

Background

Sales Orders are created in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system via the Manage Sales Order app or can be created via the API. When these sales orders are created or updated, the pricing is triggered only when certain standard fields such as item category, plant, sold-to or ship-to party is entered or updated. A custom field at the Sales Order header or item level won’t automatically trigger pricing.

The use case here is that discount code/promotion code is captured as a custom field, which can be at the header or item level dependent upon the business requirement. The discount code corresponds to a percentage, which is reflected as percentage discount in the pricing condition.

When a Sales Order is manually created and the discount code (custom field) is entered after the initial pricing has already occurred, then repricing is executed only after manually clicking update pricing at the header or item level. Also, when the sales order is created via the API, the discount code (custom field) is not taken into account in the calculation of pricing condition.

The blog describes how extensibility can be used for automatic repricing of sales orders, created via the API or via the manage sales order app in the system, when custom field (discount code/ promotion code) is populated with a specific value.

Solution using Extensibility

The solution leverages business object I_SALESORDERTP, which provides an update prices option and can be used to update the pricing condition record when discount code is populated. This is achieved by using the object to call the update pricing function immediately after the API creates the sales order or by exposing an API that automatically triggers repricing upon the creation when the discount code field is populated.

SAP BTP Event Mesh is used to generate the event and Event Consumption Model handles the event processing in the corresponding class.

Following extensibility objects are used in the solution:

1. Custom Field

Dependent upon the business requirement, whether discount code is captured at the line item or header level, custom field is created at the Sales Order Header or Sales Order Item level

a. Custom Field at Sales Order Item level

Create a custom field with business context: Sales: Sales Document Item.

Extend the custom field to the APIs:

  • Sales Order (A2X, OData V4)
  • I_SalesOrderItemTP

b. Custom Field at Sales Order Header level

Create a custom field with business context: Sales: Sales Document

Extend the custom field to the APIs:

  • Sales Order (A2X, OData V4)
  • I_SalesOrderTP

2. ABAP Class

ABAP Class is created via Developer’s extensibility. This would be singleton buffer class used to temporarily store and retrieve data related to Sales Order Header and Item values.

First, ABAP Package is created

In this step, one creates a class by providing name and description

3. Custom Business Object

Custom Business Object is used to store discount code/ promotion code and corresponding discount percentage and is created via Custom Business Objects app

In the Custom Business Objects app, create a new object, ensuring features shown below are selected.

In the Fields tab add fields relevant to the discount code e.g. discount code/description, Discount Percentage, Valid From/To date etc.

After publishing the custom business object, click Maintain Catalogs.

Add the Business Catalog „Extensibility – Custom Business Objects“ and publish it.

In the generated UI corresponding to the custom business object, maintain the relevant discount codes/ promotion codes as defined in the custom business object.

4. BADI Implementation

To manage pricing elements for Sales Order following Business Add-Ins must be implemented via Custom Logic app.

a. BADI: SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM

This BADI save values for custom fields

b. BADI:  PRCG_DOC_ITEM_CONDITION_AMOUNT

This BADI is used to update value for Item Pricing Element in the Sales Order.

In this example standard discount pricing condition „DRG1“  is updated with the discount percentage corresponding to the discount/promotion code.

Outcome:

As a result of above extensibility solution, whenever the sales order header or item custom field (discount code / promotion code) contains or is updated with valid value, the pricing is triggered reflecting discount percentage corresponding to the discount/ promotion code in the condition type DRG1.

In the below example Sales Order OData V4 API contains valid discount/promotion code (e.g. "SUMMER2025") at the item level.

The promotion code shows in Sales Order item level

The pricing condition „DRG1“ is updated with the discount percentage corresponding to the promotion code „SUMMER2025“.

Summary:

This blog showed how key user and developer extensibility objects can be used to automatically trigger pricing in Sales Order based on the custom fields.

 

Disclaimer: 

The sample code in the blog is provided as a reference implementation to demonstrate the concept. It may not cover all edge cases and should be customized, optimized and validated according to your business requirements and system design.

 

Co-authored with: @DennisLeslie

entry.title: SAP Master Data Governance in a Two-Tier ERP Landscape with HQ & Subsidiary Approach
entry.content:
Many organizations today operate in a 2-Tier ERP landscape. The typical setup is straightforward:
The headquarters (HQ) runs SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud, while regional or newly acquired subsidiaries run SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for speed, simplicity, and lower operational overhead.

This model works well from a system perspective—but it also asks some questions.
When each system manages its own master data, inconsistencies appear. Customers get duplicated, product hierarchies drift apart, and group-level reporting becomes harder with every rollout.

This is exactly where SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) fits into the picture.

Why Master Data Governance Becomes Important

In a 2-Tier environment, ERP systems are technically independent but business data is shared.
Customers, suppliers, products, and financial structures must mean the same thing everywhere.

Without a governance layer, organizations often experience:

  • Multiple versions of the same customer or supplier
  • Different product definitions across regions
  • Manual reconciliation during reporting and audits
  • Growing effort to onboard new subsidiaries

SAP MDG addresses this by introducing structure and ownership around master data—without taking flexibility away from local businesses.

How SAP MDG can be Used in a Private–Public Cloud Setup

In this landscape, SAP MDG runs at HQ on S/4HANA Private Cloud.
It becomes the central place where master data is created, validated, and approved.

Subsidiaries on S/4HANA Public Cloud do not manage governance themselves. Instead, they:

  • Receive approved master data from HQ
  • Use it operationally
  • Maintain only a small set of permitted local attributes

A simple principle guides the design:

Create and control master data centrally, consume it locally.

This keeps global standards intact while allowing subsidiaries to remain agile.

High-Level Architecture View

At a conceptual level, the setup consists of three clear layers:

  • Governance Layer (HQ – Private Cloud)
    SAP MDG defines rules, workflows, and approvals for master data.
  • Integration Layer
    Standard SAP APIs ensure secure and consistent data distribution.
  • Consumption Layer (Subsidiaries – Public Cloud)
    Subsidiaries receive governed master data and enrich it only where allowed.

Why This Matters for S/4HANA Public Cloud

S/4HANA Public Cloud is designed to stay clean, standardized, and upgrade-safe.
SAP MDG supports this philosophy by ensuring that only high-quality, compliant master data enters these systems.

As a result, organizations benefit from:

  • Fewer data-related issues in Public Cloud
  • Faster onboarding of new subsidiaries
  • More reliable enterprise reporting
  • Lower long-term data maintenance effort

Conclusion :

In a 2-Tier ERP landscape with S/4HANA Private Cloud at HQ and S/4HANA Public Cloud at subsidiaries, SAP Master Data Governance is not just a technical solution—it is a strategic foundation.

By placing governance at the center and distribution at the edge, organizations achieve:

  • Global consistency without slowing down local teams
  • A scalable ERP model for growth and acquisitions
  • Long-term alignment with SAP’s cloud strategy

Strong master data governance ensures that as systems evolve, data remains stable, trusted, and ready for the future.

entry.title: Legal Change - YATIRIMTESVIK scenario support through Extensibility in DRC Türkiye
entry.content:
This blog post introduces a guide on how to implement the new legal requirement released by GIB (GELİR İDARESİ BAŞKANLIĞI) for invoices issued under a valid Investment Incentive Certificate (Yatırım Teşvik Belgesi – YTB) through Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.


Background 
We have already published a Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud on how S/4HANA Public Cloud customers can leverage developer extensibility to modify content of XMLs produced during electronic invoice submissions, pertaining to specific business and legal requirements.

Note for: SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments: 

In SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments, the exact same process exists through extensibility, however the BAdi implementation would have to be done for EDOC_ADAPTOR instead of EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD.

What’s New? 
GIB has published a legal requirement pertaining to invoices issued under valid Investment Incentive Certificate which impacts a few companies on 21st November, 2025. In this blog we would aim to address the requirement through the learnings of the previous blog highlighted in the background.

What’s the technical specifications of the requirement? 
Currently system does not automatically determine whether a billing or finance document is YTB-related or not. The customer must explicitly indicate that the invoice belongs to a YTB investment project and provide the necessary values. As part of the legal requirement authority following is an easy requirement with an UBL (Universal Business Language, an ISO standard XML) representation:

  • New Profile IDs
    • YATIRIMTESVIK – for eInvoicing scenarios 
    • EARSIVFATURA – for eArchive scenarios 
  • New Invoice Type Codes under each invoicing scenarios
    • YATIRIMTESVIK – for eInvoicing scenarios.
      • SATIS – Sales invoices
      • ISTISNA – Exception invoices
      • IADE – Refund or Return invoices
    • EARSIVFATURA – for eArchive scenarios
      • YTBSATIS – consumer/eArchive sales invoice 
      • YTBISTISNA – consumer/eArchive exception invoices
      • YTBIADE – consumer/eArchive refund/return invoices
  • Mapping of new identification tag - ContractDocumentReference 
    • ID field should be the filled up with the incentive certificate number
      • schemeID of this would be "YTBNO"
    • IssueDate should be filled up with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format 
  • Adjustments to existing tag - TaxTotal 
    • The waived VAT amount should be shown in XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxAmount only if profileID is YATIRIMTESVIK with invoice type value is ISTISNA, or profileID is EARSIVFATURA with invoice type value is YTBISTISNA.
    • Reason codes similar to tax exemption reason codes have been introduced as part of the technical structure from GIB available at their website. These reason codes have to be filled in XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxCategory/TaxExemptionReasonCode.
    • Subsequently new reason code descriptions have also been introduced as part of the technical structure which should go in the XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxCategory/TaxExemptionReason corresponding the reason code filled in above step.
  • Adjustments to existing tag - InvoiceLine 
    • For YTB related scenarios the XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/CommodityClassification/ItemClassificationCode should be filled with 01, 02, 03, or 04 in case of the scenario of profile ID of YATIRIMTESVIK/EARSIVFATURA.
    • In case the ItemClassificationCode is 01 (Machine Equipment), and reason code in TaxExemptionReason is 308 as per the legal requirement, then
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/Name should be filled with machin name
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/ItemInstance/Name should be filled with Machine ID.
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/ItemInstance/ProductTraceID should be filled with the Machine Sequence Number/Equivalent details

How does a sample code looks like using Developer Extensibility?
